newsitem.title: JAPAN: Investigators in Nomura case raid real estate firm.
newsitem.headline: Investigators in Nomura case raid real estate firm.

text.p: Japanese investigators on Wednesday raided the offices of a real estate firm linked to a racketeer at the centre of a scandal involving Nomura Securities Co Ltd, Deputy Chief Prosecutor Kunihiro Matsuo told reporters.

He said prosecutors and officials from the nation's securities watchdog, the Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission, went to the office in Tokyo of Kojin Building Co, a firm owned by a relative of a "sokaiya" racketeer.
Matsu said there was a possibility of another round of raids on the offices of Nomura, which were raided on Tuesday.
He said 80 investigators, including 55 prosecutors, went to Kojin's office, and the raid was still taking place.
He said depending on the contents of what had been seized in Tuesday's raids, there might be a further raid on the offices of Nomura.

The headquarters of Nomura, Japan's biggest brokerage, and several other locations were raided on Tuesday. Matsuo told reporters on Tuesday the raids were to investigate a Nomura director's illegal payment of 38 million yen to a company run by a relative of a racketeer to avoid disruption of a Nomura annual meeting.

The scandal surfaced on March 6 and two directors resigned on March 10 after internal probes found they made discretionary deals banned under Japanese law and funnelled profits to a front company for the racketeer.
Sokaiya, often linked to "yakuza" crime syndicates, extort money by threatening to expose dubious business practices or to disturb shareholders' meetings -- called "sokai" in Japanese.
